runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this story is about a meerkat named Mort who uses teamwork to defend his familys burrow.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
yourself during a snowball fight or a game of tag?
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the name of the main character in the story. (Mort)
How do the meerkats defend their burrow from the lion? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why does Mort say that teamwork works?
How have you used teamwork to do something in your own life? Tell about it.
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text explains how some stories are written as if the author were talking directly to the reader.
routine. You will prompt students to use this term to talk about the story.
is a way of looking at something.
about something may be different from an adults
about a TV show or a movie with a friends
. How are they alike? How are they different?
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the name of something you can read that has a beginning, middle, and end. (story)
What is the first-person point of view? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How can a reader tell whether a story is written in the first person?
How does knowing the point of view of a story help you understand it better?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Remind students that individual sentences may be written in the first person. Point out that sentence 2 uses the word
and that these pronouns show first person.
Guide students to identify sentence 9 as written in first person. Then have students read all three sentences aloud with you.
Read the title. Explain that these are riddles. Each riddle contains a tricky question asked as a game and an answer.

For the first reading, have students read the question, and you read the answer. Then pair students to reread the riddles. Partners can switch roles during the rereadingsone asks the question, and the other answers it.
Prompt students to find and circle all the words in the riddles with spellings for
. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to the word.
Explain that students will read about how plants use spores and seeds to make new plants.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is to make copies or more of something.
Example: Plants such as corn use seeds to
a picture, what could you do?
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names what ferns grow from. (spores)
Why are spores and seeds important in helping plants reproduce? Find the sentence that answers this question.
How are spores and seeds alike? How are they different?
Corn is a seed that people eat. What are some other seeds people eat? How do you know they are seeds?
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
spellings. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Identify and discuss different types of sentences. Help students identify statements (sentences 2, 4, 5, 6, 10), questions (sentences 1, 3) and commands (sentences 7, 8, 9).
Discuss the purpose of each type of sentence and ask students to make up additional examples of each type.

Read the title. This text includes a diagram. Explain that the diagram shows the parts of a fern, including its spores. Authors include diagrams to help readers understand the parts of something that are important to remember.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the diagram.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the diagram.

Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a story about two boys who want the perfect pet.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is an agreement between two people who want different things.
Example: Jan and Mike reached a
when they decided to take turns using the computer.
Ask: When have you made a
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that tells what kind of pet Cory wants. (horse)
Why did Cory and Ben argue? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How did the boys dad come up with a compromise that made both boys happy?
Tell about an argument you have had with a sibling or friend. How did the argument end?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that Fox is the main character in this story, which is a fantasy. Ask students how they can tell when a story is a fantasy.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means being happy to give or share things.
Example: He helps many people and is
Ask: What are some of the ways people can be
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Which word names an outdoor place at Foxs home? (porch)
How does Fox show that he is generous? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why do you think Foxs neighbors surprised him?
Tell about a time when you made a new friend. What did you do?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
